title: Error message when using non-derived constants from another crate in pattern matching is confusing

labels.name: C-enhancement
labels.description: Category: An issue proposing an enhancement or a PR with one.

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-newcomer-roadblock
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error hard to understand for new users

labels.name: A-patterns
labels.description: Relating to patterns and pattern matching

body:
The error message is perfectly fine when inside the crate that has the type, because changing or adding a `derive(PartialEq, Eq)` is something you can control.

```
error: to use a constant of type `mime::Mime` in a pattern, `mime::Mime` must be annotated with `#[derive(PartialEq, Eq)]`
   --> src/main.rs:187:39
    |
187 |                     Some(&ContentType(mime::TEXT_XML)) => (),
    |                                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
```

However, when the type isn't in your crate, the message makes the user think the other crate simply "forgot" to implement `PartialEq`, and there is nothing for them to do. A suggestion would be to change the error message when the type is not a crate-local, and add a note of how to fix it.

```
error: a constant of type `mime::Mime` cannot be used in a pattern
   --> src/main.rs:187:39
    |
187 |                     Some(&ContentType(mime::TEXT_XML)) => (),
    |                                       ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
    |
    = note: try pattern guards insteand: `Some(&ContentType(ref a)) if a == &mime::TEXT_XML => (),`
```
